repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Iraq - Emergency Private Sector
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Private Sector
            Development Project for Republic of Iraq were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Grantee performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned include: in post-conflict
            settings, project preparation should proceed from as robust
            data as it is possible to obtain, along with a detailed
            analysis of the actual situation on the ground, particularly
            institutional issues and constraints. The decision to launch
            a project of this type with various components covering
            distinct sectors should be made only if there is a basic
            implementation capacity available in the respective
            ministries and preferably if champions in those ministries
            can be identified during preparation. In addition, the
            reforms to be undertaken should not be too complex for the
            available capacity. Finally, such a multi-sectoral project
            requires skillful, hands-on management from the Bank side to
            promote the needed coordination, collaboration, and
            communication across sectors and Bank unit teams. It is
            unclear whether a project based on World Bank investment
            lending procedures was appropriate so soon in the
            post-conflict and fragile conditions evident in Iraq after
            2003. In a similar post-conflict situation in the future, it
            may be more useful to find ways to help the public sector
            strengthen its internal policies, systems, and processes
            first through Bank-provided or -financed training despite
            pressure for quick project implementation. In similar post
            conflict settings, telecom infrastructure investment should
            always be complemented with this type of technical
            assistance (TA) in order to maximize impact (increased
            usage, penetration, etc.) and economic gains. The success of
            the project is linked to the overall effort that was
            sustained over time, in a context of political turmoil and
            uncertainty. While focusing on emergency needs, the project
            was also able to address capacity building issues and to set
            the basis for effective institutional strengthening. In
            countries with an unstable political environment such as
            Iraq, keeping the scope of projects straightforward and
            simple is essential. Private sector development (PSD) should
            be included in the Bank's initial support for fragile
            and post conflict environments. A focus on reconstruction
            and capacity building for PSD institutions and the
            establishment of functioning markets can play a key part in
            development of the twenty two private sector and generate
            jobs on this ground.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Additional Financing for the First
            Emergency Private Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project paper provides an additional
            financing grant to the Iraq First Emergency Private Sector
            Development Project (EPSDP I). The additional financing
            grant provided through the World Bank Iraq Trust Fund (ITF)
            will help meet the financing gap required to complete the
            implementation of the EPSDP's two telecom components:
            'upgrading of selected parts of telecommunications
            infrastructure for the payments system,' referred to as
            Iraqi Inter-Banking Network (IIBN), and 'rehabilitation
            of selected parts of national telecommunications
            network,' referred to as Microwave Network (MWN).
            Specifically, it will cover the gap created by the
            depreciation of the Dollar to Euro exchange rate and
            contract variations in the MWN contract, and provide
            contingency funds for possible contract variations for the
            IIBN and for future fluctuations in the exchange rate of the
            MWN contract. The project became effective on December 6,
            2004 and is scheduled to close on June 30, 2009. After
            experiencing initial long delays, the project has shown
            encouraging progress in 2008. Disbursements have increased
            from 9 percent in February 2008 to 41.6 percent by
            mid-October 2008. The project is expected to be fully
            disbursed by the project closing date. The implementation
            progress rating of the project has recently been upgraded to
            'moderately satisfactory' from 'moderately
            unsatisfactory'. The project management teams (PMTs)
            have strengthened their skills and staffing; have earned
            experience over the past years, and are now better equipped
            to effectively manage project implementation.

docna.cdata!:
Iraq - Additional Financing for the First
            Emergency Private Sector Development Project

Iraq - Additional Financing for
